what: A Gaussian Sliding Windows Regression Model
title: Gaussian Sliding Windows Regression
text: R package presents Sliding Windows Regression model Gaussian kernels hydrological inference, see Schrunner et al. (2023). Given input time series (xt)_t∈T(x_t)\_{t \T} (describing rainfall hydrological setting) time-dependent target variable (yt)_t∈T(y_t)\_{t \T} describing gauged watershed runoff, model utilizes set kk lagged time windows model one water path . instance, surface flow, characterized short time lags, may represented first window, groundwater flow described second window longer time lags. lagged time window WW interval time axis bounded time lags smin<smaxs_{\min} < s_{\max} relative current time point tt, W=[t−smax,t−smin].W = [t-s_{\max},t-s_{\min}]. Instead smins_{\min} smaxs_{\max}, WW represented following parameters simplicity: location parameter δ=smin+smax2\delta = \frac{s_{\min} + s_{\max}}{2} indicating window center time axis, .e. distance window center estimated time point time axis, size parameter σ=⌈smax−smin6⌉\sigma = \lceil \frac{s_{\max}-s_{\min}}{6} \rceil defining width window. Given window WiW_i, define Gaussian kernel κ()\kappa^{()} weight vector approximating shape Gaussian probability density function φ\varphi mean μ=δi\mu=\delta_i standard deviation σ\sigma. predicted runoff associated window ii computed convolution input time series (xt)_t∈T\left(x_t\right)\_{t\T} window kernel κ()\kappa^{()} weight vector, .e. κ()*xWi\kappa^{()} \ast x_{W_i}, xW=(xt−smax,…,xt−smin)x_W = (x_{t-s_{\max}},\dots,x_{t-s_{\min}}) denotes vector lagged observations *\ast denotes convolution operator. Overall, predicted output yty_t modeled multiple linear regression model yt=∑=1kβi(κ()*xWi)+εt, y_t = \sum\limits_{=1}^{k} \beta_i \left(\kappa^{()} \ast x_{W_i}\right) + \varepsilon_t, εt\varepsilon_t denotes model error. Due practical considerations, restrict regression parameters β1,…,βk\beta_1,\dots,\beta_k non-negative numbers.

title: Gaussian Sliding Windows Regression
text: core functionality package consists functions train predict, perform model fitting forecasting steps, respectively. , functions evaluating plotting model results parameters provided. implementation builds S3 class SWR, implements multiple generic functions, summary, plot, coef, dim, AIC, BIC. , evaluation metrics can computed using eval_all, calls regression performance metrics rmse (root mean square error, RMSE), nrmse (normalized RMSE), r2 (coefficient determination), well hydrological metrics nse (Nash-Sutcliffe efficiency) kge (Kling-Gupta efficientcy). Plots provided kernel vectors κ()\kappa^{()} via plot_kernel, well predictions using plot_prediction. sample dataset sampleWatershed contained package. data originates real-world watershed Cowichan, British Columbia, Canada contains daily precipitation (input time series), well gauged runoff (output time series). time series cover period 39 hydrological years, starting October 01, 1979.

title: Train model — trainSWR
text: ts_input vector ts object containing input time series ts_output vector ts object (time scale ts_input) containing target time series iter number iterations (maximum number windows) runs number independent model runs; longer supported due deterministic window initialization log whether log-linear model used parallel runs computed parallel? FALSE, runs computed serial. TRUE, runs computed parallel maximum number cores. scalar provided, number cores set manually. longer supported single-run models return either "best" (best model run returned), "" (model runs returned) param_selection either "max" (maximum number windows), "best_rmse", "best_aic", "best_bic" optimize RMSE, AIC, BIC, respectively algorithm either "GENOUD" (genetic optimization using derivatives), "BOBYQA" (bound optimization quadratic approximation)

title: Train model — trainSWR
text: object type SWR model

title: Train model — trainSWR
text: training procedure implements iterative algorithm described schrunner2023gaussianSlidingWindowReg. new window added iteration, hence number windows equals iteration counter. Input output time series provided ts_input ts_output, respectively. required equal lengths. optimization performed using GENOUD algorithm mebanesekhon2011genoudSlidingWindowReg, implemented rgenoud rgenoudSlidingWindowReg, alternatively using BOBYQA algorithm powell2009bobyqaSlidingWindowReg, implemented nloptr nloptrSlidingWindowReg. training hyperparameter, iter indicates number iterations, equals maximum number windows selected model. Parameters return param_selection indicate criterion used determine number windows; option : return="" (hyperparameter selection) return="best", allows one following options: param_selection="best_aic": select model lowest AIC, param_selection="best_bic": select model lowest BIC, param_selection="best_rmse": select model lowest RMSE. Arguments runs, parallel deprecated used.

title: Train model — trainSWR
code: # train a model based on one year of observations set.seed(42) data(sampleWatershed) mod <- trainSWR(sampleWatershed$rain[1:365],                 sampleWatershed$gauge[1:365],                 iter = 2) #> Warning: The `runs` argument of `trainSWR()` is deprecated as of SlidingWindowReg 0.1.1. #> ℹ Multiple model runs are not useful with deterministic window initializations. #> Warning: The `parallel` argument of `trainSWR()` is deprecated as of SlidingWindowReg #> 0.1.1. #> ℹ Parallel model runs are not useful with deterministic window initializations. #> Warning: The `return` argument of `trainSWR()` is deprecated as of SlidingWindowReg #> 0.1.1. #> ℹ Return argument is unused. summary(mod) #> SlidingWindowReg (SWR) model object with k = 2 windows #>  #> | window| delta| sigma| beta| #> |------:|-----:|-----:|----:| #> |      1|  0.17| 21.28| 0.36| #> |      2|  0.86|  0.36| 0.67| #>
